Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Response individuality in collectively oscillating biofims

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The cell is the fundamental unit of life. However, cells in nature rarely lead a solitary existence, but rather reside in large communities, much like most of the human population on our planet resides in cities. Even bacteria, which are single cell organisms are predominantly found within communities known as biofilms. This provokes a fundamental question: How much independence does the individual cell retain when it is part of a community? Specifically, does the individual cell, or the community, determine the response to a local perturbation? There is an urgent need to address this question, since a bacterial cell within the biofilm community can be thousand times more drug resistant than the same bacterium living in solitude. Antibiotics typically target biochemical processes within individual cells. Therefore, knowledge on how biological systems balance the need for cellular individuality versus collective coordination would improve strategies to curtail deleterious effects or enhance the beneficial ones. In line with the goals of the NSF, this research exemplifies interdisciplinary research and applies concepts from the field of mathematics and physics to solve a fundamental problem in biology. As such, it will provide an excellent training opportunity not only for the graduate student and postdoc, but also for the many undergraduate and high school students with diverse backgrounds that receive training in the investigator?s laboratory.

The investigator has recently uncovered that bacterial biofilms exhibit global oscillations in protein aggregation and growth. Motivated by this breakthrough, he proposes to develop a prototype microfluidic device in which the response of an individual bacterium can be tracked within large biofilms. The PI will integrate the data collected with a mathematical theory based on the Phase Response Curves that revolutionized the study of circadian rhythms. He will develop a novel microfluidic system that will allow the precise determination. how cells within a biofilm community respond to a local perturbation. The question of individuality versus collective behavior remains unresolved not only in biology, but also across all the physical sciences. The investigator also pursues the unprecedente prediction that the observed relatively long-range (milimeter distances) coordinaton of population behavior is unlikely due to the diffusion of chemical signals, but rather, derives from by radical gases associated with aging bacterial populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our work constitutes a technical and biological breakthrough in our understanding of bacterial communities also known as biofilms. Born out of the need to quantitatively measure the behavior of biofilm communities, we developed a new microfluidic-based technique. This innovation allowed us to uncover that metabolic activity in biofilms is organized in space and time. We thus overturned the traditional view that biofilm formation is a monotonic process by demonstrating a fitness strategy based on nonlinear dynamics (oscillations). We revealed a connection between topics that are typically considered to be unrelated: nonlinear dynamics and biofilm resilience.

 

Our next study constitutes a landmark paper that reports the profound discovery that, similar to neurons in the brain, bacteria communicate via electrical signaling mediated by ion channels. This study was directly motivated by our previous discovery of globally coordinated oscillations during biofilm development that had indicated the existence of an active communication mechanism in biofilms. The involvement of charged metabolites in global biofilm oscillations provoked the hypothesis that bacterial membrane potential could play an important role. This hypothesis turned our attention to ion channels known to be critical regulators of membrane potential.

 

Directly inspired by on our discovery of potassium ion channel-mediated electrical signaling within biofilm communities, we hypothesized that waves of extracellular potassium propagating through the biofilm could extend beyond the boundary of the community. Since biofilms often reside in aqueous environments surrounded by planktonic motile cells, we speculated that electrical signaling could affect the membrane potential and thus behavior of such cells at a distance. Indeed, in our publications we presented the discovery that bacterial biofilm communities can actively modulate the motile behavior of distant bacterial cells through electrical signaling. We thus show that a biofilm can exert long-range and dynamic control over the behavior of distant cells that are not part of its community.

 

Collectively, our work has uncovered an unexpected behavior within bacterial communities: Bacteria engage in long-range coordination of distant cells, which is mediated by electrochemical signaling made possible by ion channels.  Our body of work thus established a prokaryotic paradigm for long-range coordination using ion channels.
